conclusion: The problem involves shadows cast by four different objects on a stone slab, labeled A, B, C, and D.
The task is to determine how these shadows change when the light source moves backwards, considering both location and size.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a light source.
The position and size of the shadow depend on the position of the light source and the object.
If the light source moves, the shadow will also move and possibly change in size.
Shadow is formed on the side opposite to the light source, relative to the object.
The longer the distance between the object and the light source, the shorter the shadow.
Conversely, the closer the object is to the light source, the longer the shadow.
When the light source moves, the shadow moves in the opposite direction.
If the light source moves farther away from the object, the shadow becomes smaller.
If the light source moves closer, the shadow becomes larger.
Object B looks like a red box with a black base.
Object C appears to be a black lamp or some sort of cylindrical object.

premise: When the light source moves backwards, the shadow should move towards the object because the light is moving away from the object.
conclusion: Shadow A should move closer to the object.

premise: Since the light source is moving farther away from the object, the shadow should become smaller.
Similar to object A, when the light source moves backwards, the shadow should move towards the object.
conclusion: Shadow B should move closer to the object.

premise: The size should decrease as the light source moves farther away.
With the light source moving backwards, the shadow should move towards the object.
conclusion: Shadow C should move closer to the object.
